headline: 1941: Arms to Ireland Weighed
text: HYDE PARK, N.Y. — President Roosevelt, indicating that he is well satisfied with the progress of some phases of the national defense program but dissatisfied with others, revealed today [June 27] that he is considering sending some rifles to Ireland, but that the United States cannot spare ammunition to go with them. The President made it clear that no arms will be sent to Eire until the United States receives assurances that they will be used to repel any Nazi invasion. — New York Herald Tribune, June 28, 1941

headline: Pro-‘Brexit’ City of Sunderland Glad to Poke Establishment in the Eye
text: SUNDERLAND, England — In places like Sunderland, with its once-robust shipyards silent and dead and its citizens leery of both London and Brussels, the idea of the European Union never really took hold.

headline: A Plastic Glass to Enjoy Drinking From
text: The undeniable practicality of plastic glassware for outdoors is combined with attractive design in these glasses from Pubware. There’s a stemless wine glass, heavy in the hand and thin at the drinking edge, while still thick enough to insulate so the rosé stays cool. The same thoughtful design applies to the 16-ounce beer glass, as well as a 20-ounce version, a rocks glass and a cordial. All are dishwasher-safe and BPA-free, and claim resistance to clouding and cracking: Pubware,  $24.99 to $54.99 for four glasses, $17.99 each with monogram or other lettering, pubware.com.

headline: Reactions to the Supreme Court Ruling on Texas’ Abortion Law
text: In a major abortion ruling Monday, the Supreme Court struck down parts of a Texas law that would have forced dozens of clinics to close. Here are reactions from all sides of the issue.

headline: Made to Order for an Authentic Scampi
text: Scampi in Italy are not shrimp. They’re langoustine tails, and fresh wild ones from Iceland — very large, sweet and moist but firm — are available at FreshDirect. Extract the meat to toss in a sauté pan with good olive oil, garlic, parsley and a splash of white wine, or boil them in very salty water for about six minutes to serve chilled with a sauce: Wild langoustines, $5.99 each, $18 for four, three to four a pound, freshdirect.com.

headline: A Nordic Food Hall in Grand Central Terminal
text: The vision behind this collection of Nordic-accented food stands in the stately landmark Vanderbilt Hall at Grand Central Terminal belongs to Claus Meyer, the Danish food entrepreneur, a partner in Noma who is juggling several projects in New York. As a food hall, not a market, it is all about prepared food to eat in or take out. The bakery stand, Meyers Bageri, has breads, pastries, sandwiches and whole grain flatbreads with various toppings including richly burnished cauliflower. Open Rye specializes in smorrebrod open-faced sandwiches and the Grain Bar starts the day with granolas, then segues into a beer bar after 4 p.m. Almanak specializes in salads and smoothies and will soon offer small plates. A seating area with waiter service is adjacent, as is a liquor bar: The Great Northern Food Hall, Vanderbilt Hall, Grand Central Terminal, greatnorthernfood.com.

headline: Jewish Cookbook Exhibit and History Lecture
text: Among the many thousands of books and artifacts at the Center for Jewish History are cookbooks and manuscripts. A small but well-curated selection of them is on display. Bonnie Slotnick, who owns the vintage cookbook store in the East Village, will talk about the books June 29 in a lecture starting at 6 p.m. The cookbooks come from the collections of the five partner organizations of the Jewish history center, including the Yeshiva University Museum and the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research: “Nourishing Tradition: Jewish Cookbooks and the Stories They Tell” through Sept. 9, Center for Jewish History, 15 West 16th Street, 212-868-4444, cjh.org. Admission to the talk and a reception afterward is free with reservations, cjh.org/event/2895.

headline: For Fourth of July, Sausages With Provolone and Pickled Peppers
text: Just for the Fourth of July, Yankee Red Hots sausages are being sold to take home from Pig Beach, a seasonal, mostly outdoor restaurant serving smoked meat overlooking the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. The links are made in-house from pork riddled with bits of provolone and pickled hot cherry peppers. The restaurant smokes them before grilling; home cooks should roast them at 250 degrees for 20 minutes, then brown them on the grill or in a skillet. As they cook, they ooze cheese: Yankee Red Hots, $20 for four to pick up at Pig Beach, 480 Union Street (Bond Street), Gowanus, Brooklyn, 718-737-7181, pigbeachnyc.com; to order in advance at info@pigbeachnyc.com.

headline: Ah, a Cocktail at the Ritz’s Bar Hemingway in Paris
text: A cocktail at the Ritz Paris is more compelling than ever. A renovation has given the hotel three bars instead of two. First choice is still the wood-paneled memorabilia-filled Bar Hemingway in the back. There, Colin Field mixes drinks like the Mach2, four parts Scotch and two parts green Chartreuse with a good splash of ginger syrup, served on the rocks and light and refreshing enough for summer. Opposite is the new Ritz Bar, bistro-style with food all day and a deep wine list. And then there is Bar Vendôme, steps from the hotel’s main entrance and a magnet for fashionistas: Ritz Paris, 15, place Vendôme, Paris, 011-33-1-43-16-30-30.

headline: Making Art From Pakistan’s Chaos
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — A drain, clogged with pink plastic bags and filled with black water, separates Bahar Colony, a Christian neighborhood, from the rest of this city. On one side is the Arfa Software Technology Park, a soaring modern complex of steel and green glass. On the other, the broken facades of low-lying brick houses are hung with rags. A sign reads: “Faith Gospel Assemblies, Lahore.”

headline: Takata Airbag Linked to Another Death in Malaysia
text: TOKYO — An airbag made by the auto supplier Takata has been linked to a crash that killed a woman in Malaysia over the weekend, the vehicle’s manufacturer said on Monday.

headline: Disney Princesses Do Change Girls — and Boys, Too
text: When you’re a parent of children of a certain age, the Disney princesses seem to be everywhere.

headline: 10 Great Monday Reverie Recipes
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking seven days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: ‘Veep’ Season 5 Finale: Hell to the Chief
text: What does it mean to be a sitcom called “Veep” that’s no longer about a vice president? Even though Selina Meyer has been the actual POTUS for two of this show’s five seasons, the whole time she’s been campaigning to secure an office that she was never actually elected to — which means that, in a way, she’s remained in a political purgatory. Whether sitting in the first or second chair, Selina’s never really had any “mandate.” She’s never had much political capital to spend, or any ambitious set of initiatives to spend it on.

headline: Kurdish Rebels Clash With Iran’s Revolutionary Guards
text: TEHRAN — Kurdish rebels and Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps have engaged in armed clashes along the mountainous Iranian border with Iraq in recent days, raising tensions in the region, Iranian state television reported.

headline: What to Do When a Wild Animal Attacks
text: Run or fight? That is the question prompted by a series of recent animalattacks on humans, including an alligator that dragged a 2-year-old to his death in an Orlando lake last month. And CNN reported recently that a mountain lion in Colorado had attacked a 5-year-old boy, who was saved when his mother pried the child away from the animal.

headline: Pew Research Center: On Race and Inequality, Blacks and Whites Are Worlds Apart
text: Black and white Americans experience life in profoundly and persistently different ways, according to a new Pew Research Center survey.

headline: Touches of Whimsy at World Trade Center’s Liberty Park
text: “This is one of the most beautiful garages in the world,” Steven Plate said about the 25-foot-high structure that leads into and out of the underground vehicle security center at the World Trade Center.

headline: Reaction to Texas Abortion Decision
text: On Monday, the Supreme Court struck down parts of a restrictive Texas law that would have severely limited abortion access in the state. Activists outside the Supreme Court reacted to the news.

headline: RJR Nabisco Ruling Bolsters Justice Dept.’s Pursuit of FIFA
text: The government may not always get what it wants from the Supreme Court, but federal prosecutors received exactly what they asked for last week when the justices decided in a case involving RJR Nabisco, the food and tobacco conglomerate, how far the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO, applies to foreign conduct.

headline: Jordan Ellenberg: The Lottery Scheme
text: This week’s challenge was suggested by Jordan Ellenberg, a math-world superstar and current professor of mathematics at the University of Wisconsin. Jordan is the child prodigy who turned out well. After teaching himself to read at age 2, he attained a perfect 800 on the math portion of the SAT at age 12, won two gold medals in the International Math Olympiad (with perfect scores), and was a two-time Putnam Fellow at Harvard.

headline: An Enduring Heroin Market Shapes an Enforcer’s Rise and Fall
text: Up the block came three young men, shoelaces lapping at the sidewalk, faces half-hidden in hoods, to pay their respects to a fallen street soldier.

headline: Spirit Airlines Wants to Stay Cheap but Not So Tawdry
text: It’s the airline that had unabashedly advertised its product as a “cheap seat for a cheap-ass.”

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: More Americans Say Race Relations Are Bad, and a Survey Explores Why
text: Black and white Americans experience life in profoundly and persistently different ways, according to a new Pew Research Center survey examining racial attitudes in the United States.

headline: What You Should Watch if You’re Missing a Favorite Show
text: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small, famous and esoteric, to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. Our most recent suggestions also appear below. To receive our guide straight to your inbox, sign up here.

headline: Atop the Gymnastics World, Simone Biles Can’t Suppress Her Grin
text: ST. LOUIS — At the end of the United States women’s gymnastics championships here on Sunday night, so many gold medals hung around Simone Biles’s neck that when she walked, they clinked so loudly it made her giggle. A few times, she grabbed her medals to silence them and laughed yet again.

headline: The W.H.O. Versus the C.D.C.
text: Ask The Times, a Times Insider feature, draws on New York Times expertise to answer questions about current events, science, sports, culture and whatever else is making headlines.

headline: Making Mochi, a Japanese Treat That’s All About Texture
text: Sometimes the pleasures of food aren’t packed in remarkable tastes, but in textures. And when it comes to mochi, the Japanese rice dough, much of its appeal can be attributed to a glorious bounce or a gelatinous squish or a comforting kind of gloop.

headline: U.S. Investigates Whether Airstrikes Killed Taliban Hostages
text: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — American airstrikes in northern Afghanistan killed at least seven hostages being held in a Taliban prison on Saturday, according to accounts from the families of victims and local officials from the immediate area. Some accounts put the death toll as high as 16.

headline: Wild, Wonderful, Wacky Hair on the Men’s Runways
text: On the fall/winter 2016 runways, designers from Comme des Garçons to Gosha Rubchinskiy festooned men’s heads in spiky hair, flower crowns and splashes of color.

headline: What Leaders Said Before ‘Brexit,’ and What They Say Now
text: Political leaders on both sides of the debate in Britain over whether to leave the European Union are now saying distinctly different things about some central issues than what they said before the referendum. Here are some examples.

headline: Opinion Transforms Texas’ Abortion Landscape
text: HOUSTON — The Supreme Court’s ruling Monday tossing out two of the main elements of Texas’ 2013 law regulating abortion, one of the most stringent in the country, has transformed the environment for abortion in the state.

headline: A Narrow Diversity at Vassar
text: To the Editor:

headline: No Steph Curry. No LeBron James. It Won’t Matter for U.S. Basketball in Rio
text: Stephen Curry isn’t on the team, and neither is LeBron James or Russell Westbrook. Nor is Kawhi Leonard, Chris Paul or James Harden.

headline: 1916: Hughes Hits Out at President
text: NEW YORK — In response to a telegram informing him that the Progressive National Convention had decided to support him for the Presidency of the United States, Judge Hughes, the Republican candidate, telegraphed his thanks last night [June 26] for the Convention’s support in the common cause which would assure national security and honor. Judge Hughes added that the grave difficulties with which the present Wilson Administration is confronted are due to its own weakness and indecision. ‘‘I am convinced,’’ wrote the Republican candidate, ‘‘that prompt and decisive action would have prevented the tragedy of the Lusitania.’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 28, 1916

headline: Central American Refugees
text: To the Editor:

headline: American Ballerina Leaps Into Euro-Sorcery in a Gothic Fairy Tale
text: There’s a part of us that delights in watching seemingly perfect things be mussed up, taken down or wickedly exposed. Ballet is an art form that often wraps itself in purity and propriety, but there’s pleasure in occasionally watching it get nasty, as it did in the 2010 film “Black Swan” and last year’s TV series “Flesh and Bone.”

headline: On Bill Cunningham: ‘Dim the Lights on Seventh Avenue’
text: To the Editor:

headline: House Democrats Release Benghazi Report to Blunt Republican Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — House Democrats on Monday moved to pre-empt the findings of a two-year Republican-led investigation into the attacks in Benghazi, Libya, in which four Americans were killed, by issuing their own 339-page report that cast the inquiry as a politically motivated crusade that wasted time and money.

headline: In ‘Dead of Summer’ on Freeform, Horrors Await Campers
text: The summer-camp horror genre, so familiar to moviegoers, gets a hair-raising television incarnation in “Dead of Summer,” a series that starts Tuesday, June 28, on Freeform. It’s 1989, and Camp Stillwater looks lovely as the young counselors (one of them played by Zelda Williams, Robin’s daughter) arrive to get ready for the season. Most were campers there themselves as children, but there’s also a newbie, Amy (Elizabeth Lail), who is somewhat skittish for reasons that are doled out slowly.

headline: Brahms Sonatas, Pianissimo From Taka Kigawa, Zorn’s Bagatelles
text: Even during a relatively sleepy week on New York’s classical calendar, there are tantalizing performances. On Sunday, June 26, the violinist Johnny Gandelsman and the pianist Ethan Iverson come together for Brahms’s three sonatas at Bargemusic, a cozy spot for chamber music. (4 p.m., Fulton Ferry Landing, next to the Brooklyn Bridge, bargemusic.org.)

headline: Bill Callahan to Perform in Brooklyn
text: The work of the singer-songwriter Bill Callahan has become intensified with purpose over the last 10 years; the songs on “Dream River,” his last studio album, from 2013, can seem as if they were constructed one word at a time, one sound at a time, to be sung in his soft, abstracted baritone voice. Yet, weirdly, the songs aren’t stiff; they’re light-bodied and place trust in the universe. (“I have learned,” he sang in the last lines of “Winter Road,” that record’s final song, “when things are beautiful/to just keep on.”)

headline: Revisiting Hubert Robert and His Romantic Ruins
text: Although not well known today, Hubert Robert was one of the most popular painters of 18th-century France. Renowned for landscapes in which ancient monuments and modern buildings were arranged in imaginary scenes called architectural capriccios, he was nicknamed “Robert des ruines” by the philosopher Denis Diderot. An interior decorator and landscape designer as well, he frequented intellectual and artistic circles that included the painter Élisabeth Louise Vigée le Brun and the Enlightenment philosopher Marie Thérèse Rodet Geoffrin.

headline: Obama White House Veterans Gleefully Enter the Podcast World
text: David Axelrod was having a candid conversation with an old colleague when, almost accidentally, the two made some news.

headline: Executive Summary of the Democrats' Report on Benghazi
text: House Democrats released a report on Monday to pre-empt the findings of a Republican-led investigation into the attacks in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012.

headline: An 8th Straight Week at No. 1 for Drake’s ‘Views’
text: The big winner on the music chart this week? Streaming. The loser, if there is one, is sales.

headline: World’s Largest Uncut Diamond Heads to Auction, a Break With Tradition
text: The world’s largest uncut diamond is about to be sold in a most uncommon way.

headline: Why Aren’t We Managing Children’s Pain?
text: It began with a simple roller-skating accident three years ago. Taylor Aschenbrenner, then 8 years old, lost her balance amid a jumble of classmates, tumbled to the floor and felt someone else’s skate roll over her left foot. The searing pain hit her immediately.

headline: Hotels That Help You Fight Jet Lag
text: “It’s annoying to be in a great destination and not enjoy it because your body isn’t adjusted to the current time,” said Michael Holtz, the founder of the New York City travel consultancy SmartFlyer, who makes more than two dozen international trips a year.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Is Locking In the Forces That Already Haunt the Global Economy
text: Sometimes, something bad happens, and it creates huge financial market swings and long-lasting economic ripples. The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks were an example, as was the 2011 Japanese nuclear disaster.

headline: Men’s Fashion Shows: Thom Browne, Paul Smith and Lanvin
text: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections that were presented in Paris on Sunday.

headline: Reasons Behind the British Vote to Leave the E.U.
text: To the Editor:

headline: How ‘The Sleeping Beauty’ Tells Its Story Through Ballet
text: Does the Tchaikovsky ballet “The Sleeping Beauty” tell a story, or is it just a nonstory? On the face of it, the ballet demonstrates the opposite of suspense. It has a prologue and three acts — but, before the Prologue is over, two rival divinities, the vengeful Carabosse and the beneficent Lilac Fairy, have told us what’s going to happen. So guess what? Then it happens. What’s more, it all happens during Acts I and II. Act III has no narrative at all, just the happy couple’s wedding and their fairy tale guests. The whole thing sounds daft.

headline: A Connecticut Tribe Fights for Recognition, and a Piece of the Casino Industry
text: In Connecticut, two Indian tribes, the Mohegans and the Mashantucket Pequots, years ago built shiny monuments to American capitalism in the form of their casinos, which have made them extraordinarily wealthy.

headline: Bad Behavior Is Exposed as the Shale-Oil Market Shrinks
text: A legal case against the self-described Frack Master is a sure sign that the so-called bezzle in the shale-oil industry is shrinking.

headline: Donald Trump’s Running Mate?
text: Last week we asked readers to advise Hillary Clinton on her running mate. Now we turn to the Republican ticket. Whom do you think Donald Trump should pick, or will pick, and why?

headline: StubHub Will Serve as Yankees’ Ticket Reseller
text: After years of feuding, the Yankees and StubHub announced an agreement on Monday under which the company will become the team’s official ticket reseller but with caveats that include a floor on how much tickets can be discounted.

headline: Supreme Court’s Abortion Decision Reverberates in Presidential Campaign
text: The Supreme Court’s decision to strike down parts of a restrictive abortion law in Texas rippled through the presidential campaign after its release on Monday, with Democrats and Republicans looking to rally voters with reminders that the future of the court was at stake in November.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Finale: Nikolaj Coster-Waldau on Cersei’s Madness and Jaime’s Evolution
text: Jaime Lannister set the tone for “Game of Thrones” in the pilot episode, shoving the young Bran Stark out of a window, paralyzing him, in the first of the show’s many unspeakably cruel acts.

headline: Diplomatic Deal With Turkey Upsets Israelis Wary of Conceding Too Much
text: JERUSALEM — As Israeli and Turkish leaders announced the formal resumption of full diplomatic relations after a six-year fissure, the front page of the popular Hebrew newspaper Yediot Aharonot summed up the predicament for many Israelis: “Reconciliation or surrender.”

headline: As Migrants Face Abuse, Fear That ‘Brexit’ Has Given License to Xenophobia
text: LONDON — In Birmingham, protesters held a banner outside a mosque that said “rapefugees not welcome.”

headline: Italy Displays New Flair as Spain Shows Its Age
text: ST.-DENIS, France — The first two days of the knockout rounds at the European Championships were wholly, and remarkably, forgettable. The Wales-Northern Ireland game was drab. Croatia-Portugal was dreary. France offered just one decent half against Ireland. Belgium-Hungary felt like a limp.

headline: Meet the Lingerie Brand Marieyat
text: The line, now in its second collection, consists mainly of high-waisted and medium-rise underwear, bras and bodysuits.

headline: Brand to Know: Subversive, Super-Comfortable Lingerie
text: When a pair of much-loved underwear starts sprouting holes, most people throw them in the trash. But for the London-based designer Marie Yeung, it was a pair of tattered undergarments that inspired her to start an underwear line, Marieyat, last year. “I was over at my friend Gwyneth’s house, and she was doing what girls do — showing each other clothes, putting on outfits, taking them off, putting them on again,” recalls Yeung. “I see that she is wearing a pair of underwear, made of a really sheer delicate fabric and that the binding has ripped, because they’re falling apart and because she just wears them at home, and obviously doesn’t care. The binding was so perfectly cut, just under the butt cheek. And I realized, this is actually appealing in a really weird way.”

headline: Pastors Praise Anti-Gay Massacre in Orlando, Prompting Outrage
text: After the massacre in Orlando, Fla., American religious leaders spoke in a largely unified voice, condemning the killer and mourning the dead. But at some extreme conservative Christian churches, there was another message: good riddance.

headline: An N.Y.U. Study Gone Wrong, and a Top Researcher Dismissed
text: New York University’s medical school has quietly shut down eight studies at its prominent psychiatric research center and parted ways with a top researcher after discovering a series of violations in a study of an experimental, mind-altering drug.

headline: When You Write a Memoir, Readers Think They Know You Better Than They Do
text: I once knew a woman who had been famously kidnapped as a child. She confessed to me that she longed to talk about her kidnapping, but no one ever brought it up. “Why?” she wondered. The story had been in print, after all, the subject of national headlines; it preceded her into every room. She was left with an acute sense of apartness, her unspoken story roiling inside her. “What am I supposed to do?” she asked me. “Pick up the phone and call Patty Hearst?”

headline: The Problem With Modern Policing, as Seen From the Right and From the Left
text: Ferguson, Mo. The name alone identifies the problem, though it typically is reinforced by an equally familiar roll call: Eric Garner, Michael Brown, Laquan McDonald, Tamir Rice, Walter Scott. Since 2014 the nation has been engaged in an endless debate about whether it is crime or policing that is out of control.

headline: AstraZeneca Pushes to Protect Crestor From Generic Competition
text: No more than a few hundred American children have a rare disease characterized by ultrahigh levels of bad cholesterol.

headline: In Paris, It’s a Cruel Fashion Summer
text: PARIS — For weeks, hundreds of fashion professionals have been following fashion shows much the way that groupies once followed the Grateful Dead: in like-minded packs, across countries and nations, communicating among themselves in their own argot, focused to the exclusion of nearly everything else on the entertainment at hand.

headline: Getting Back on the Court at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Shortly after 11:30 a.m. Monday, on Court 4 in the shadow of Centre Court, Daria Kasatkina won the first point of the 2016 Wimbledon tournament.

headline: Review: ‘The Return,’ a Son’s Pained Search for a Missing Father
text: Toward the end of this eloquent memoir, Hisham Matar quotes these words, spoken by Odysseus’ son Telemachus in “The Odyssey”:

headline: Celebrating Black Culture With a Careful Eye
text: Sarah Lewis studies photography and its power to shape ideas of race and identity with a depth few others can match. Before joining the faculty at Harvard, where she is an assistant professor of history of art and architecture and African and African-American studies, she held curatorial positions at the Museum of Modern Art and the Tate Modern, where she often shaped provocative exhibitions dealing with race, representation and other topics.

headline: A Major Victory for Abortion Rights
text: In the most significant victory in a generation for a woman’s right to make decisions about her own body, the Supreme Court  on Monday struck down Texas’s harsh and dishonest anti-abortion law by a vote of 5 to 3.

headline: History in the Making
text: The recent installation of a series of historical photographs in The New York Times’s third-floor newsroom provides a chance to reflect on snapshots from the paper’s history.

headline: Review: ‘Dead of Summer’ Tugs at Horror and Mystery
text: Before Adam Horowitz and Edward Kitsis (with Ian Goldberg) created the new series “Dead of Summer” for Freeform, they worked on a little show called “Lost.” Knowing that might keep you watching “Summer,” about young counselors at a haunted summer camp, longer than you would otherwise. It would be a small satisfaction to find out that these dimwits were dead all along.

headline: Edward Snowden Criticizes ‘Big Brother’ Measure in Russia
text: MOSCOW — Edward J. Snowden, an American who took refuge in Russia after leaking a trove of classified United States data from global surveillance, has criticized a proposed Russian law as an assault on freedom of speech, and has been rebuffed in an effort to collect a free-speech prize in Norway.

headline: In ‘Game of Thrones,’ the Pleasures of a Quickened Pace
text: This article includes spoilers for Season 6 of “Game of Thrones.”

headline: For ‘The Color Purple,’ a Delayed Box Office Bump
text: “The Color Purple” got its post-Tonys bounce, one week late.

headline: Chicago and Jazz at Play, Ideally
text: There are a couple of ideal notions about jazz that I wish were more often true in practice. One is about regionalism: that a place, and the experience people have living in that place, shape the sound of the music. The other is about relativity of style: that musicians drawn to different parts of the jazz tradition can have no problem playing together.

headline: Gay Catholic Groups Want Pope Francis to Do More Than Apologize
text: ROME — Leaders of gay Catholic groups on Monday praised Pope Francis for saying that all Christians and the Roman Catholic Church owed an apology to gays for previous mistreatment, even as the groups called on the church to take more concrete steps to repudiate past teachings and condemn anti-gay violence.

headline: Review: ‘Here I Sit, Broken Hearted,’ Answering Nature’s Call With Bathroom Humor
text: An hourlong exercise in puerile scatology, Seth Panitch’s “Here I Sit, Broken Hearted … A Bathroom Odyssey,” at the Samuel Beckett Theater, seemingly aspires to emulate, oh, perhaps, “The Book of Mormon” in its exaltation of the coarse and the crude. In skits built around men’s room graffiti, the show fleshes out primitive anatomical renderings and dime store doggerel with song, dance and lightning-fast comic riffs. But its frantic exertions and straining after wit prove exasperating.

headline: Putting Breast Cancer on a Diet
text: Should weight loss be prescribed as a treatment for breast cancer?

headline: The Facts Win Out on Abortion
text: SOMEONE landing from Mars on Monday and coming upon Justice Stephen G. Breyer’s majority Supreme Court opinion in the Texas abortion case would have had no hint of the decades-long battle over women’s right to abortion and the dogged efforts by states to put obstacles in their way.

headline: With Phillips Auction, Art Market Feels Effects of ‘Brexit’
text: LONDON — The art market on Monday night felt the first effects of Britain’s momentous “Brexit” vote when Phillips held an auction of 20th-century and contemporary art at its grand European headquarters in London.

headline: Williams Appeals Delaware Decision to End Pipeline Merger
text: Shareholders of the Williams Companies voted on Monday to approve a merger with Energy Transfer Equity, the Dallas-based pipeline operator, paving the way for Williams to appeal a Delaware judge’s decision last week that allows the deal to be terminated.

headline: On a Heating Planet, ‘Gasland’ Filmmaker Josh Fox Lets Go and Loves
text: Josh Fox’s first and second films, “Gasland” and “Gasland Part 2,” were high-octane polemics aimed at ending fracking, shorthand for the revolutionary method of fracturing deep layers of shale to liberate natural gas and oil previously deemed unreachable. From “The Cove” (on Japan’s dolphin hunts) to “Pandora’s Promise” (on the benefits of nuclear energy) this strategy, meshing a film and a campaign, has become commonplace.

text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: No Speaking Slots? Ted Cruz and John Kasich Brush Off Trump’s Threat
text: Ted Cruz and John Kasich have a message for Donald J. Trump: They don’t care if they are not invited to speak at his convention.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: The Alternative Medical Bill: $30.2 Billion
text: Americans spend $30.2 billion a year on alternative and complementary medicines and procedures, including $1.9 billion on children 4 to 17 years old. None of it is covered by insurance.

headline: Upset Loss to Iceland Has England Gnashing Its Teeth
text: England lost a game on Monday. That has happened before.

headline: Peter Hutton, Filmmaker With Austerely Romantic Worldview, Dies at 71
text: Peter Hutton, an experimental filmmaker noted for his contemplative, sensuous, masterfully photographed portraits of landscapes and cities, died on Saturday in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 71.

headline: Florida Jury Finds Former Chilean Officer Liable in ’73 Killing
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Four decades after the bullet-riddled body of the Chilean folk singer Víctor Jara was discovered in the mayhem of the military coup that upended his country, Mr. Jara’s family found some measure of justice on Monday in a Florida courtroom.

headline: Why the Supreme Court’s Texas Abortion Decision Is So Momentous
text: Monday morning, the United States Supreme Court struck down parts of a Texas law that would have significantly reduced the number of abortion clinics in the state. Emily Bazelon, a staff writer for the magazine; Eric Posner, a professor at the University of Chicago Law School; and William Baude, an assistant professor at the University of Chicago Law School, have been exchanging emails about the meaning and impact of the court’s decision.

headline: Volkswagen to Pay $14.7 Billion to Settle Diesel Claims in U.S.
text: Volkswagen has agreed to pay up to $14.7 billion to settle claims stemming from its diesel emissions cheating scandal, in what would be one of the largest consumer class-action settlements ever in the United States.

headline: Seeking to Improve Ties With Russia, Turkey Apologizes for Downing Warplane
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey continued its diplomatic fence mending on Monday, apologizing for downing a Russian jet near its border with Syria last year.

headline: Abortion Ruling Could Create Waves of Legal Challenges
text: From Texas to Alabama to Wisconsin, more than a dozen Republican-run states in recent years have passed laws requiring that abortion clinics have hospital-grade facilities or use doctors with admitting privileges at nearby hospitals.

headline: A Single Senator Stymies the Export-Import Bank
text: WASHINGTON — Thursday is an ignominious anniversary for the government agency that helps finance foreigners’ purchases of American exports. Thanks to a single senator, it has been a full year since the 82-year-old Export-Import Bank could approve deals exceeding $10 million, a limit that rules out high-dollar deals on airplanes, power generators, heavy equipment and nuclear reactors.

headline: How Britain Could Exit ‘Brexit’
text: WASHINGTON — In the days since Britons voted to leave the European Union, the so-called “Brexit” referendum has created such severe turmoil that public attention is increasingly focused on an extreme option: Can they get out of it?

headline: Michael Graves’s Residence, Rejected by Princeton, Is to Be Sold to Kean University
text: Kean University, home of the nascent Michael Graves College for architecture and design, has received permission from its board of trustees to purchase three of Graves’s properties in Princeton, N.J. — including his residence and studio, the Warehouse — for $20.

headline: Spain’s Vote Deals Setback to Podemos, a Rising Protest Party
text: MADRID — While no party emerged with a clear mandate from Spain’s second round of national elections over the weekend, the results did demonstrate that it was possible, after all, to stop the advance of Europe’s protest parties.

headline: Emigrant Savings Bank Discriminated Against Minorities, Brooklyn Jury Says
text: A federal jury in Brooklyn found on Monday that the Emigrant Savings Bank had discriminated against eight minority homeowners by purposefully marketing to them subprime mortgages with what were described as predatory interest rates of as much as 18 percent a year.

headline: Sam Bell, Exacting Mentor of College Runners, Dies at 88
text: Sam Bell, who turned out some of America’s best middle-distance runners as a college track and field and cross-country coach, died on Monday in Bloomington, Ind., the home of Indiana University, where he had spent most of his 40-year career. He was 88.

headline: What the Volkswagen Settlement Could Mean for Car Owners
text: Volkswagen has agreed to pay almost $15 billion to settle claims in the United States over its diesel emissions scandal, affecting nearly half a million cars. This is what that could mean for vehicle owners:

headline: Climate Change High on Agenda as Obama and Trudeau Meet for Summit
text: OTTAWA — When Justin Trudeau, the prime minister of Canada, appeared at the United Nations this spring to sign the Paris climate accord, the rapturous ovation he received was worthy of the celebrity he had become, a leader full of promise and of promises, especially on climate change.

headline: Justices Decline to Hear Case Limiting Debt Collectors
text: The Supreme Court declined on Monday to hear a case that could undermine the ability of some lenders to charge high interest rates.

headline: Supreme Court Complicates Corruption Cases From New York to Illinois
text: WASHINGTON — After Dean G. Skelos, the once-powerful New York state senator, was sentenced last month on federal corruption charges, one of his lawyers asked the judge to allow Mr. Skelos to remain free on bail while he appealed his conviction.

headline: Unicef Says Its Development Goals for Children Are at Risk
text: The United Nations said Monday that its global development goals for 2030 were at risk of failure, estimating that if current trends continue, nearly 70 million children will die from mostly preventable causes and that 750 million girls will be married while still children.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Doesn’t Mean Game Over, but It May Be Just the First Domino
text: This isn’t meant to scare you, but let’s consider the absolute worst-case scenarios of “Brexit.”

headline: Dominican Candidates in New York Tout Their Pioneer Status, but History Is Complicated
text: In the race to replace Representative Charles B. Rangel, the buzz around two of the candidates, Adriano Espaillat and Guillermo Linares, has been heightened by their chance to make history: Each is seeking to become the first person born in the Dominican Republic to be elected to Congress.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I think it is absolutely essential that we stay focused on how, in this transitional period, nobody loses their head, nobody goes off half-cocked, people don’t start ginning up scatterbrained or revengeful premises, but we look for ways to maintain the strength that will serve the interests and the values that brought us together in the first place.”

headline: American Swimmers Leave Father Time in Their Wake
text: OMAHA — At her first Olympic trials, Dana Vollmer was upset because she did not win. Never mind that she was 12 years old, the youngest competitor striving to qualify for the United States team in 2000. After she tied for 43rd in the 100-meter butterfly, Vollmer stomped off the pool deck scowling.

headline: Pitching Woes Threaten Foundation of the Mets’ Hopes
text: WASHINGTON — Pitching is the bedrock of the Mets’ championship hopes. The ground shook below them before Monday’s game, then crumbled during it. More nights like this will swallow up the season.

headline: Donald Trump Hires Former Adviser to Ted Cruz
text: Donald J. Trump has hired a veteran political strategist and former adviser to Senator Ted Cruz as his de facto communications director, a significant move as Mr. Trump shifts toward a more traditional campaign structure.

headline: Wimbledon: Marcus Willis Beat the Odds. Next Up Is Roger Federer.
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Roger Federer, tennis’s perennial sentimental favorite, will have to surrender that crown on Wednesday.

headline: Accused in Two Rapes, Former Student at Indiana University Avoids Prison With Plea Deal
text: A former Indiana University student who was charged with rape in two separate cases in September accepted a plea deal last week in which both felony charges were dismissed and he was sentenced to a year’s probation with no prison time for a misdemeanor.

headline: Long Way to Go
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — One of my favorite stories when I was a child was E. B. White’s “CHARLOTTE’s Web.” I loved the book, I loved the 1973 cartoon and I especially loved CHARLOTTE, who was a mother-figure to the piglet Wilbur.

headline: For the Second Year, Rents in Some Stabilized Apartments in New York City Will Not Increase
text: The board that sets rents for more than one million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City voted on Monday to freeze rents for one-year leases for the second year in a row.

headline: Randy Levine Has Strong Words for Reporters, Not Yankees
text: As president of the Yankees, Randy Levine can be a feisty defender of his team. And he seemed in a particularly combative mood Monday when asked about the Yankees’ struggles to get above .500 and whether the team would end up a buyer or a seller as the July 31 trading deadline approached.

headline: Elaborate Suicide Attack Hits Christian Village in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Eight suicide bombers launched two waves of attacks on the Christian town of Al Qaa in northeastern Lebanon on Monday, killing at least five people and raising fears that violence from the civil war in neighboring Syria will further destabilize Lebanon, its fragile neighbor.

headline: Katie Ledecky Falls Short of a Record but Gains a Challenger
text: OMAHA — Katie Ledecky was answering questions from reporters after winning the 400-meter freestyle Monday night at the United States Olympic swimming trials when a roar from the warm-down area drowned out her voice. The explosion of noise was for Leah Smith, the second-place finisher, who had arrived to cool down after giving Ledecky a roof-raising race at CenturyLink Center.

headline: Cuomo and Billy Joel Ride for Breast Cancer Awareness
text: It is probably safe to say that in the history of bill signings by governors in the State of New York, few, if any, featured the entrance that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo made on Monday.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Takes a Seat Again as the Yankees Cite His Anemic Numbers
text: Alex Rodriguez emerged from the Yankees’ clubhouse two hours before the game against the Texas Rangers on Monday at Yankee Stadium. He hunched over on the dugout steps, looking meditatively out at the field.

headline: Somewhere, John Sorensen, 92, Is Smiling
text: John Sorensen turned 92 the day after Christmas, and from the first time I met him, almost a year earlier, he said he wanted to die. Some days he had a sense of humor about it. “The only thing about dying,” he said one day, “is that I won’t be alive long enough to enjoy the fact that I finally died.”

headline: Amra Sadikovic Faces Serena Williams at Wimbledon Two Years After She Walked Away
text: WIMBLEDON, England — For Amra Sadikovic, a 27-year-old Swiss player who is facing Serena Williams in the first round Tuesday, playing at Wimbledon has been a dream 18 years in the making — except for a 14-month stretch in which she gave up on it entirely.

headline: Noah Syndergaard Exits Early, Putting Mets on Alert
text: WASHINGTON — In the midst of a third-inning meltdown Monday, Mets starter Noah Syndergaard summoned catcher Travis d’Arnaud to the mound. Something was not right with Syndergaard; his command had oddly disappeared. Moments later, Syndergaard called for d’Arnaud again, and boos rained down from Washington Nationals fans.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: “Frontline” investigates reform within the Newark Police Department after a three-year Justice Department investigation. “Dead of Summer” goes back to camp in the 1980s, where scary campfire stories come to life. And “Very British Problems” returns, with James Corden and David Tennant.

headline: Order of Business for E.U. in Brussels? Weeds, Then ‘Brexit’
text: BRUSSELS — Less than 24 hours after Britain threw Europe’s postwar order into disarray last Thursday by voting to leave the European Union, dozens of officials from the bloc’s 28 member countries and its executive arm met behind closed doors in a drab Brussels office block to discuss the urgent issues at hand.

headline: Corrections: June 28, 2016
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Markets Move Toward Stability After ‘Brexit’ Turbulence
text: Financial markets regained some equilibrium on Tuesday after days of turbulence following Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.

headline: 졸업생들에게 전하는 메시지: 지금은 매우 힘든 시대지만, 여러분은 해낼 수 있습니다
text: 만약 졸업식 축사가 우리가 사는 시대를 반영한다면, 올해 미국 대학교 졸업식 축사들은 우리에게 다가올 날이 힘겨울 수 있음을 시사한다. 그렇지만 여전히 희망의 끈을 놓지 않을 이유는 있다.

headline: A New Treatment for Dogs Scared by Thunder and Fireworks
text: It is entirely possible that no one dreads the dog days of summer more than dogs themselves.

headline: NASA’s Juno Spacecraft Arrives at Jupiter
text: The Juno spacecraft successfully entered orbit around Jupiter on July 4.

headline: Juno: Piercing Jupiter’s Clouds
text: On July 4, 2016, NASA’s Juno spacecraft arrived to study Jupiter after a trip of nearly two billion miles.

headline: NASA’s Juno Spacecraft Will Soon Be in Jupiter’s Grip
text: After traveling for five years and nearly 1.8 billion miles, NASA’s Juno spacecraft will announce its arrival at Jupiter with the simplest of radio signals: a three-second beep.

headline: Marine Le Pen : Après le Brexit, le printemps des peuples est inévitable !
text: PARIS — S’il est bien une chose qui chatouille l’orgueil d’un Français, c’est qu’un Anglais vienne lui voler la vedette. Mais devant la valeur du courage, même le Français le plus fier ne peut que s’incliner : il ne lui reste qu’à tirer son chapeau. Et c’est bel et bien un acte de courage que la décision que vient de prendre le peuple britannique, le courage de ceux qui assument leur liberté.

headline: Marine Le Pen: After Brexit, the People’s Spring Is Inevitable
text: PARIS — IF there’s one thing that chafes French pride, it’s seeing the British steal the limelight. But in the face of real courage, even the proudest French person can only tip his hat and bow. The decision that the people of Britain have just made was indeed an act of courage — the courage of a people who embrace their freedom.

headline: Election Choices From the Editorial Board
text: Here are some recommendations in today’s Democratic primary races for Congress in New York. The polls in New York City will be open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

headline: Revolt of the Masses
text: Anybody who spends time in the working-class parts of America (and, one presumes, Britain) notices the contagions of drug addiction and suicide, and the feelings of anomie, cynicism, pessimism and resentment.

headline: From Uruguay, a Model for Making Abortion Safer
text: With the announcement in April that the Zika virus spreading across Latin America can cause microcephaly in the womb, leaders across the region have come under increased pressure to relax some of the world’s most restrictive laws against abortion.

headline: The Brexit Spillover
text: Economic policy makers had already turned cautious even before Britain voted last week to leave the European Union. This month, when the Federal Reserve refrained from raising interest rates, chairwoman Janet Yellen cited uncertainty over the outcome as a reason to wait.

headline: Brexit Proponents’ False Promises Crumble
text: Well, that didn’t take long. Some of the most prominent politicians behind the “Leave” campaign are backing away from the false claims and dubious promises that they made in the run-up to the referendum to take Britain out of the European Union.

headline: Don’t Mess With Texit
text: Arthur Brooks: What a week, Gail. The Brits decide to leave the European Union. Anyone who doubts that major nations can take a big populist turn just got a wake-up call, to put it mildly. Everyone wonders who’s next. The Dutch? The French? I’ve been seeing a lot on Twitter about “Texit,” which Greg Abbott, the governor of Texas, apparently felt the need to explain won’t be happening.

headline: How to Save Venezuela
text: What should be done to address the civil, economic and humanitarian crisis in the country?

headline: Yankees Wait, and Wait, and Wait, and Then Lose
text: Before the start of the ninth inning of the Yankees’ game against the Texas Rangers on Monday night, Aroldis Chapman warmed up in the bullpen, preparing to help the Yankees escape with a one-run victory in what had become a rain-soaked affair.

headline: Oakland Votes to Block Large Shipments of Coal
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The city of Oakland, Calif., on Monday banned the transport and storage of large coal shipments, a blow to a developer’s plans to use a former Army base as an export terminal to ship coal to China and other overseas markets.

headline: Airbnb in Disputes With New York and San Francisco
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb has charmed and strong-armed lawmakers around the world to allow it to operate in their communities. But two cities, Airbnb’s hometown, San Francisco, and New York, the service’s largest United States market, have not been so compliant.

headline: How Young Soldiers Saw Life in Wartime Vietnam
text: A new exhibit of photos made by young soldiers in war zones features poignant images of daily life in a distant, and dangerous, land.

headline: ‘The Arrangements’: A Work of Fiction
text: The New York Times Book Review asked the acclaimed novelist Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie to write a short story about the American election. A second work of election fiction — by a different writer — will follow this fall.

headline: How Young Soldiers Saw Life in Wartime Vietnam
text: The photographs are almost banal.

headline: A Sea of Charter Schools in Detroit Leaves Students Adrift
text: DETROIT — On the face of it, Ana Rivera could have had almost any choice when it came to educating her two sons. For all the abandoned buildings and burned-down houses in her neighborhood in the southwest part of this city, national charter school companies had seen a market and were setting up shop within blocks of each other, making it easier to find a charter school than to buy a carton of milk.

headline: It’s Dogs vs. Poachers in the Fight to Protect Elephants
text: The government of Tanzania has gone to the dogs in its effort to stop the flow of ivory taken from elephants.

headline: Takata Chief Executive to Resign as Financial Pressure Mounts
text: TOKYO — The chief executive of Takata said on Tuesday that he would step down, as the embattled car parts supplier looks to attract much-needed financial support to deal with the fallout from the largest automotive safety recall in history.

headline: Adichie on Mrs. Trump
text: In an election season widely seen as stranger than fiction, we decided to turn to fiction to see how it might illuminate today’s befuddling political climate. For the first time ever, the Book Review has commissioned an original short story. The assignment: Write anything about this election season you like. The result, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s “The Arrangements,” on our cover this week, updates Virginia Woolf’s “Mrs. Dalloway” — with Melania Trump as Clarissa.

headline: ‘Brexit,’ Abortion, Euro 2016: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New York Today: Offbeat Playgrounds
text: Updated, 6:45 a.m.

headline: Four States Hold Congressional Primaries
text: The presidential primaries are history, but plenty of congressional preliminaries remain, with Tuesday’s round featuring some crucial matchups in Colorado, New York and Oklahoma.

headline: Morning Agenda: Market Panic Subsides as Britain Faces Economic Fears
text: MARKET PANIC SUBSIDES AS BRITAIN FACES ECONOMIC FEARS | Markets regained some equilibrium in Asia on Tuesday with the pound clawing back some of its losses and the Nikkei 225 rising in Japan, Jonathan Soble reports in DealBook.

headline: Zika Bill Is Blocked by Senate Democrats Upset Over Provisions
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Tuesday blocked a federal spending bill that would have provided $1.1 billion to fight the mosquito-borne Zika virus, saying Republicans had sabotaged the legislation with politically charged provisions. The move raised the possibility that no new money would be available soon to fight the disease as Southern states brace for a summer outbreak.

headline: Pat Summitt, Tennessee Basketball Coach Who Emboldened Women’s Sports, Dies at 64
text: Pat Summitt, who was at the forefront of a broad ascendance of women’s sports, winning eight national basketball championships at the University of Tennessee and more games than any other Division I college coach, male or female, died on Tuesday. She was 64.

headline: Donald Trump Versus the ‘Haters’
text: You know how it is. You have it all. Riches, fame, hotels, this beautiful wife, the world’s greatest line of neckties. You had a hit television show and now you have a hit presidential campaign. And the more you have, the more people want to get in your face for having it. You can’t even skip a lousy Republican debate — because the moderator you previously insulted still displeases you — to hold a fund-­raiser for America’s veterans without reporters asking, months later, where the money went. Then there’s this impending trial over that defunct “university” of yours. The school promised to make students rich but wound up making many of them even poorer, and now they’re suing.

headline: Luigi Ghirri’s Brilliant Photographic Puzzles
text: I look at Luigi Ghirri’s work daily: There’s a postcard reproduction of one of his photographs on my fridge. It depicts four women, turned away from us and toward a mountainous landscape. They could be taking in an actual vista — the perspective is correct — but the mountains and their intervening lakes have text superimposed on them, and so we realize the women are standing before an image of a landscape, either a poster or a mural. Ghirri took the photograph in Salz­burg, Austria, in 1977. I find it reassuring, amusing (that slight stutter in parsing it), simultaneously simple and complex in ways that are difficult to explain.

headline: Donald Trump Vows to Rip Up Trade Deals and Confront China
text: MONESSEN, Pa. — Donald J. Trump vowed on Tuesday to rip up international trade deals and start an unrelenting offensive against Chinese economic practices, framing his contest with Hillary Clinton as a choice between hard-edge nationalism and the policies of “a leadership class that worships globalism.”

headline: Viggo Mortensen Goes Off the Grid With ‘Captain Fantastic’
text: Despite its title, “Captain Fantastic,” which opens Friday, July 8, couldn’t be less like a superhero movie. It stars Viggo Mortensen, who has both the looks (the piercing blue eyes and jutting Kirk Douglas chin) and the buff physique of a Marvel type, but would probably prefer slow death to putting on a cape and tights.

headline: The Humiliating Practice of Sex-Testing Female Athletes
text: One day in June 2014, Dutee Chand was cooling down after a set of 200-meter sprints when she received a call from the director of the Athletics Federation of India, asking her to meet him in Delhi. Chand, then 18 and one of India’s fastest runners, was preparing for the coming Commonwealth Games in Glasgow, her first big international event as an adult. Earlier that month, Chand won gold in both the 200-meter sprint and the 4-by-400-meter relay at the Asian Junior Athletics Championships in Taipei, Taiwan, so her hopes for Scotland were high.

headline: A Blunt Message After ‘Brexit’: Bolting Will Carry a Heavy Price
text: BRUSSELS — Shaken by Britain’s vote to quit the European Union, the bloc’s leaders met on Tuesday in Brussels and sent a blunt message to Britain and others tempted to follow its example: Bolting will carry a heavy price.

headline: Chappatte: The Brexit Hangover
text: Britons look for a cure.

headline: A Guide to Catching Up on ‘Brexit’ and Reading the Tea Leaves
text: WASHINGTON — Since more than 17 million people voted for Britain to disengage from the European Union, every news cycle brings word of a head-spinning new possibility. Might the United Kingdom disunite? Can the world’s financial markets continue their seismic turmoil indefinitely? Could the referendum be reversed, rejected or repeated?

headline: Pat Summitt, a Coach Who Belonged on the ‘Mount Rushmore of Women’s Sports’
text: Summitt, who was inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 2000, was a trailblazer, ambassador and missionary.

headline: 10 Months, 45 National Parks, 11 Rules
text: When I was 12, my family piled into a Honda Odyssey and headed west for a summer exploring the national parks. That trip changed my life. I tasted the freedom of the open road and experienced the wonders of America’s wild places. I was hooked.

headline: 10 Free (or Cheap) Travel Apps Worth Downloading
text: After a week of downloading and trying out various travel and navigation apps, I reached an unfortunate conclusion: Most of them are worthless — clunky, buggy, seemingly desultory efforts by developers rushing a poor product to market. There are a few, though, that provide elegant solutions to some of travel’s more common complications, doing what a good app should do: make life easier. Here are seven free travel apps that are worth your time, and three that are worth your money.

headline: Not Forgotten: Franz Ferdinand, Whose Assassination Sparked a World War
text: World War I began with the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand by an 18-year-old student in Bosnia.

headline: In ‘Brexit’ and Trump, a Populist Farewell to Laissez-Faire Capitalism
text: Donald J. Trump and Boris Johnson: Is this how the era ushered in by Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher finally ends?

headline: Despite ‘Brexit’ Uncertainty, Anya Hindmarch Is Adding Men’s Wear
text: All the question marks surrounding Britain’s vote to leave the European Union and what it means for British businesses, not to mention the confusion about the future of the men’s wear season, which ended in Europe on Sunday (New York men’s wear begins July 11), has not stopped a growing group of British women’s wear designers from deciding that now is a good time to get in on the men’s market.

headline: After Orlando Shooting, ‘False Flag’ and ‘Crisis Actor’ Conspiracy Theories Surface
text: After the mass shooting at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla., on June 12, Twitter brimmed with news reports of the carnage. But some posts on the massacre that claimed 49 lives also included a curious phrase: “false flag.”

headline: Chinese Court Orders Apology Over Challenge to Tale of Wartime Heroes
text: BEIJING — For decades, the “Five Heroes of Langya Mountain” have been presented as courageous examples of how the Communist-led Eighth Route Army fought for the Chinese people against the Japanese invaders in World War II.

headline: California Today: How Badly Do You Want That New Rail Line?
text: Good morning.

headline: Jason Day, World’s Top Golfer, Pulls Out of Olympics Over Zika Fears
text: Jason Day, the No. 1-ranked golfer in the world, became the latest player to pull out of the Olympics because of concern over the Zika virus.

headline: Amazon Kindle Learns to Navigate Literary Thickets
text: SEATTLE — For years, Amazon has been chiseling away at the irritants that keep many people from switching to e-readers. The company has improved the legibility of the text on Kindle screens to make it nearly indistinguishable from print, and fiddled with the ergonomics of the new Kindle Oasis to make using it feel more like holding a book.

headline: Rent Battle: Tenants vs. Landlords
text: Inside one of the loudest public meetings in New York, with tenants chanting and yelling and landlords trying to influence the Rent Guidelines Board’s vote on a rent increase.

headline: VW’s U.S. Diesel Settlement Clears Just One Financial Hurdle
text: Volkswagen solved one big problem stemming from its diesel emissions deception,  agreeing on Tuesday to pay up to $14.7 billion to settle claims in the United States.

headline: House Benghazi Report Finds No New Evidence of Wrongdoing by Hillary Clinton
text: WASHINGTON — Ending one of the longest, costliest and most bitterly partisan congressional investigations in history, the House Select Committee on Benghazi issued its final report on Tuesday, finding no new evidence of culpability or wrongdoing by Hillary Clinton in the 2012 attacks in Libya that left four Americans dead.

headline: The Growing Cost of a Hospital Stay
text: If you have to go to the hospital, health insurance is supposed to cushion the financial blow. But as insurers pass more costs along to patients, hospitalizations are getting more expensive, and checking in can come with a four-figure bill.

headline: Handicapping the Odds of a Clinton Landslide
text: Based on evidence from the last three decades, polarization in American politics has eliminated landslide presidential victories.

headline: A Symbol of Southwestern China
text: The streets of Chongqing, an industrial city in China, once teemed with a “bang-bang army,” as residents call porters. Now they are disappearing.

headline: The Last ‘Bang-Bang’ Men
text: On the steep streets of Chongqing, impoverished porters, known as “bang-bang,” help carry goods for anyone willing to pay a small fee. But today their occupational existence is under threat.

headline: ‘Destined to Disappear’: The Last Generation of China’s ‘Bang-Bang Army’
text: CHONGQING, China — After shouldering loads up and down steep hills here for 35 years, Niu Dancheng knows the exact number of stairs to the Yangtze River docks where he often finds work as a porter. There are 128 to Dock 8 at Chaotianmen port, he said, which he had just descended with 90 pounds of roasted duck for a cruise ship.

headline: Buddy Ryan, Combative Defensive Genius in the N.F.L., Dies at 85
text: Buddy Ryan, pro football’s famously combative defensive innovator, who helped propel the Jets and the Chicago Bears to Super Bowl championships, died on Tuesday in Shelbyville, Ky. He was 85.

headline: ‘Anastasia’ Musical Sets Broadway Opening
text: Twenty years after they created the music for the animated film “Anastasia,” the composers Stephen Flaherty and Lynn Ahrens will see their songs reach their usual haunt — Broadway — with the opening of the stage musical of the same name, which producers announced on Tuesday.

headline: With Cataracts, My Own Private Light Show
text: Over the past three years I’ve been plagued by one of the common curses of aging: cataracts. During that time my vision gradually deteriorated, as the normally transparent natural lenses of my eyes became increasingly opaque, going from a gentle soft focus, to gauzy, then cloudy, and ultimately downright foggy. This was apparently the result of some unhappy combination of sun exposure, age, a number of potentially insidious environmental and dietary factors, and just plain genetic bad luck. (My mother and two of my brothers also suffered from this condition.)

headline: Having Won, Boris Johnson and ‘Brexit’ Leaders Fumble
text: LONDON — With their giddy celebrations of “independence day” having given way to political and economic turmoil, one thing has become especially clear about the former London mayor Boris Johnson and other leaders of the successful campaign to vote Britain out of the European Union: They had no plan for what comes next.

headline: 1966: Bloodless Coup Ousts Regime in Argentina
text: BUENOS AIRES — The armed forces seized control of Argentina today [June 28] in a swift, bloodless coup. President Arturo Illia, a former country doctor, was ousted. A tough, anti-communist general, Juan Carlos Ongania, was named to succeed him. The commanders of the army, navy and air force said they deposed the 65-year-old doctor because of his failure to cope with Argentina’s economic problems and to keep the ‘‘Peronistas’’ out of any form of power. The rightist generals and admirals moved swiftly at the climax of more than a month of simmering tension between them and the government. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 29, 1966

headline: A.I.’s Grasp of Diversity May Begin With Who Builds It
text: Last week, the magazine Science published a thought-provoking article about what sort of morality people would like their self-driving cars to have.

headline: At Home in London, Not Britain
text: LONDON — Eight weeks ago, I was among those celebrating Sadiq Khan’s election as the new mayor of London. The victory felt symbolic: Mr. Khan, a state-school-educated son of a bus driver who immigrated from Pakistan, had been given the largest personal mandate of any politician in British history. I am the same age as Mr. Khan and I’m also a state-educated son of Pakistani Muslim immigrants, and so his win felt especially validating for me. London had sent a message that it was open, tolerant and welcoming. This city, where I have lived for almost 20 years, was really a place I could feel comfortable and call home.

headline: Downloading Video Streams to Go
text: Q. Several streaming music services allow you to listen without an internet connection — are there any video-streaming services that let you download a movie to a tablet for watching on a plane?

headline: Pelvic Exams May Not Be Needed
text: Many women dread the indignity of the annual pelvic exam, in which they are poked and prodded with their feet in stirrups.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Finale Draws Record Ratings
text: The Season 6 finale for “Game of Thrones” drew the largest audience in the history of the series, with 8.9 million viewers tuning into HBO on Sunday night, according to Nielsen.

headline: Palantir Buyback Plan Shows Need for New Silicon Valley Pay System
text: Palantir Technologies’ $225 million offer to repurchase its employees’ privately held shares hints that Silicon Valley is starting to make some fundamental changes in the way it compensates its workers.

headline: ‘UnREAL’ Season 2 Episode 4: ‘We Made All of This Happen’
text: On “UnREAL,” energy can turn to chaos any moment. The tight focus of the first season kept this from happening too often; the thing most in danger of falling apart was usually Rachel. This season though, between producer battles, network interference, an injured suitor and Rachel and Quinn’s power struggle, “Everlasting” itself is threatening to shake loose. When Rachel begs Romeo to keep Darius on the show, she breathlessly tells him: “We made all of this happen. We can fix it.” It’s meant to sound like a promise between them — but ‘we’ could mean anyone, and it sounds a lot more like dismay.

headline: Walking Meditation
text: A 15-minute walking practice led by Sharon Salzberg.

headline: Ending Spain’s Political Deadlock
text: On Sunday, just three days after Britain’s shocking vote to leave the European Union, Spanish voters returned to the polls for the second time in six months to elect a government. In December, two upstart parties, Podemos and Ciudadanos, buoyed by a wave of voter frustration with the political establishment in a country hit hard by economic crisis and austerity, turned Spanish politics upside down, ending more than three decades of alternating governance by Spain’s two major parties, the conservative Popular Party and the Socialists. The resulting Parliament was too fractious to form a government, forcing new elections.

headline: Peril on Wings: 6 of America’s Most Dangerous Mosquitoes
text: With the spread of the Zika virus, the threat posed by the tiny mosquito has been magnified into shark-size proportions.

headline: Drug Testing Lab in Kazakhstan Is Suspended
text: Days after suspending the laboratory that was supposed to handle drug testing at the Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, the World Anti-Doping Agency, the global regulator of drugs in sports, announced Tuesday that it had suspended Kazakhstan’s antidoping lab as well.

headline: Small Plates Hold Court at Freek’s Mill in Brooklyn
text: A corner spot in Gowanus joins the farm-to-table movement.

headline: Freek’s Mill Spins Romance Near a Superfund Site
text: Standing on a drawbridge one night early this month, a man and a woman stood close and kissed, blind to everything around them, even the motionless toxic porridge of the Gowanus Canal below their feet. About to cross the span, I stopped to give them their space. The Union Street Bridge in Brooklyn is not the Pont Marie in Paris. But romance can bloom anywhere, even on a Superfund site.

headline: How Much Will ‘Brexit’ Stress Banks? Some Ways to Tell
text: Among all the anxieties that Britain’s decision to leave the European Union has provoked, here’s another one: Are big banks going to be in trouble?

text: Dear Diary:

headline: Jeremy Corbyn, Leader of Britain’s Labour Party, Loses No-Confidence Vote
text: LONDON — Britain’s opposition Labour Party, already reeling after voters defied its advice and chose to leave the European Union, was plunged further into crisis on Tuesday when its leader, Jeremy Corbyn, overwhelmingly lost a no-confidence motion among his fellow lawmakers.

headline: Notes on a Gazan’s Visit to Israel
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. Majd al Waheidi is a Gaza-based “stringer,” a freelance reporter who regularly contributes to The Times. In this piece, she describes a recent — and, for her, a rare — trip to Israel.

headline: In an All-British Match, No. 2 Andy Murray Beats a Feisty No. 235
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Andy Murray is the only British man to win the Wimbledon singles title since 1936. Last year he led Britain to its first Davis Cup championship since 1936. He has been figurehead and head cheerleader for British tennis for most of his career.

headline: Senators Press for Answers After Prepaid Debit Cards Fail
text: As regulators prepare to strengthen rules for prepaid cards, lawmakers are pressing Walmart, MasterCard and Green Dot to explain what went wrong last month when shoppers using Walmart prepaid debit cards were unable to get access to their accounts.

headline: 1916: Highlanders Win Against Huns
text: LONDON — Bad weather, with torrential downpours of rain, has failed to damp the ardor of the British troops now engaged in smashing down the elaborate network of enemy defences barring the road to Lille and holding the mine basin of the North of France under the German boot. Heavy toll was taken during the night [June 27] by incursions into the enemy’s trenches, and the British troops, attacking with swiftsure energy, were invariably able to execute their mission with almost negligible losses. The Highland Light Infantry earned particular distinction. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 29, 1916

headline: Jenny Slate on the Great Pleasure of Tiny Animals
text: In this series for T, the writer and author of “Worn Stories,” Emily Spivack, interviews creative types about their most prized possessions.

headline: Fresh Mango, Multiple Ways in a Single Dessert
text: For many New Yorkers, the mango dessert being served this summer at Indian Accent, the chef Manish Mehrotra’s restaurant in Midtown, is likely to come as a revelation. Think of it as a study in mango, a series of poetic variations that pay tribute to the fruit’s versatility.

headline: Chinese Textbook Calls Women Who Have Premarital Sex ‘Degenerates’
text: BEIJING — Young women who have sex before marriage are degenerates. A girl who gives her body for love will make the boy who “conquers” her love her less. Premarital sex has a “tremendous negative psychological and physical impact on girls.”

headline: Germs in the Subway Are the Harmless Kind
text: Those subway poles you avoid touching because you’re convinced they are covered with harmful germs may not be as dangerous as you thought.

headline: Aska Gives Its New-Nordic Food a New Home
text: Aska Fredrik Berselius’s decision to use the name of his last restaurant for his next one came late in the game. And it was one of the few easy parts of building and opening the new place. The tall, lanky Swedish chef, who closed his much-lauded new-Nordic restaurant two years ago, went through months of searching for space, then ran into complications with construction. Now, almost a year late, the square black room, one corner of which is taken up with an open kitchen, is ready. “I did not want one of those long, narrow dining rooms,” Mr. Berselius said. The restaurant has a spacious garden and a downstairs white-brick bar and lounge. (The dining room has no bar, like a growing number of restaurants.) For his 12- to 15-course tasting menus, which change daily, he is considering dishes like hake smoked in hay, and dry-aged beef with cured beef fat and salted gooseberries. Mr. Berselius is planning to find as many ingredients as possible in the Northeast; caviar from Finland will be one of his few imports. (Opens Tuesday): 47 South Fifth Street (Wythe Avenue), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 929-337-6792, askanyc.com.

headline: Is ‘Brexit’ Europe’s Lehman Brothers Moment?
text: Is this another Lehman Brothers moment?

headline: The Right-Wing Supreme Court That Wasn’t
text: WASHINGTON — Conservatives thought this Supreme Court term would be different.

headline: Paul Draper of Ridge Vineyards to Retire
text: Paul Draper, who as winemaker and chief executive has led Ridge Vineyards for more than 45 years as it became one of the world’s most celebrated wine producers, is retiring, Ridge will announce on Wednesday.

headline: Israeli Military Revokes Use of Maximum Force to Foil Captures
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military has canceled a contentious directive known as the Hannibal procedure, which calls for the use of maximum force to prevent the capture of Israeli soldiers, even at the risk of harming them.

headline: An Immigrant’s Contribution to Mount Rushmore Is Recognized, 75 Years Later
text: Set in stone is supposed to mean immutable, but Luigi Del Bianco’s determined descendants just now appear to be winning the official affirmation that the Italian-American from Westchester County deserved long ago for shaping one of the nation’s most famous monuments.

text: To the Editor:
